entry.title: Advanced Techniques and Strategies in EXAFS Analysis
Application of Two-dimensional correlation Analysis in XAS
entry.content:
Initially developed approximately 30 years ago in NMR spectroscopy, two-dimensional spectroscopy facilitated the visualization of complex spectra characterized by numerous overlapping peaks by distributing them across a second dimension. While NMR remains the predominant technique in two-dimensional spectroscopy, this approach has been extended to other forms, proving particularly useful across various spectroscopic techniques.

Brief overview of 2D correlation spectroscopy

History of 2D COS

Feature of 2D Correlation Spectra

Cases

Case 1: IR 2D-COS

DOI:

Case 2: XAS 2D-COS

DOI:

Principle of 2D correlation spectroscopy

How to Perform 2D Correlation Analysis

Software for 2D correlation Analysis

2D correlation spectroscopy with XAS

How To Interpret The 2D COS of XAS

References

Reference
  1. Al Lafi, A. G. (2018). "Application of 2D correlation methods to the analysis of XPS spectra of ion irradiated poly (ether ether ketone)." Journal of Polymer Research 25(4).
  2. Choi, H. C., et al. (2003). "A study of the mechanism of the electrochemical reaction of lithium with CoO by two-dimensional soft X-ray absorption spectroscopy (2D XAS), 2D Raman, and 2D heterospectral XAS− Raman correlation analysis." The Journal of Physical Chemistry B 107(24): 5806-5811.
  3. Choi, H. C., et al. (2006). "Application of soft X-ray absorption spectroscopy and two-dimensional correlation spectroscopy to the electrochemical reaction in the Li1+ xV3O8/Li cell." Journal of molecular structure 799(1-3): 91-95.
  4. Lim, S., et al. (2005). "Pore curvature effect on the stability of Co-MCM-41 and the formation of size-controllable subnanometer Co clusters." J Phys Chem B 109(6): 2285-2294.
  5. Liu, Y. and H. He (2009). "Experimental and theoretical study of hydrogen thiocarbonate for heterogeneous reaction of carbonyl sulfide on magnesium oxide." J Phys Chem A 113(14): 3387-3394.
  6. Nakashima, K., et al. (1999). "Two-dimensional infrared correlation spectroscopy studies of polymer blends: conformational changes and specific interactions in blends of atactic polystyrene and poly (2, 6-dimethyl-1, 4-phenylene ether)." The Journal of Physical Chemistry B 103(32): 6704-6712.
  7. Noda, I. (1993). "Generalized two-dimensional correlation method applicable to infrared, Raman, and other types of spectroscopy." Applied Spectroscopy 47(9): 1329-1336.
  8. Noda, I. (2000). "Determination of two-dimensional correlation spectra using the Hilbert transform." Applied Spectroscopy 54(7): 994-999.
  9. Noda, I. (2014). "Two‐Dimensional Correlation Spectroscopy Study of Polystyrene." Macromolecular Symposia 339(1): 17-23.
  10. Noda, I., et al. (2000). "Generalized two-dimensional correlation spectroscopy." Applied Spectroscopy 54(7): 236A-248A.
  11. Pazderka, T. and V. Kopecky Jr (2008). "2D correlation spectroscopy and its application in vibrational spectroscopy using Matlab." Tech. Comput. Prague: 978-980.
  12. Šašić, S., et al. (2000). "A New Possibility of the Generalized Two-Dimensional Correlation Spectroscopy. 1. Sample− Sample Correlation Spectroscopy." The Journal of Physical Chemistry A 104(27): 6380-6387.
  13. Šašić, S., et al. (2000). "A New Possibility of the Generalized Two-Dimensional Correlation Spectroscopy. 2. Sample− Sample and Wavenumber− Wavenumber Correlations of Temperature-Dependent Near-Infrared Spectra of Oleic Acid in the Pure Liquid State." The Journal of Physical Chemistry A 104(27): 6388-6394.
  14. Sui, H., et al. (2017). "Determination of the radiation resistance order of high explosives by the two dimensional correlation X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy." Nuclear Instruments and Methods in Physics Research Section B: Beam Interactions with Materials and Atoms 406: 496-500.
  15. Zhang, J., et al. (2018). "A novel method of three-dimensional hetero-spectral correlation analysis for the fingerprint identification of humic acid functional groups for hexavalent chromium retention." RSC Adv 8(7): 3522-3529.
  16. Noda, I., & Ozaki, Y. (2005). Two-dimensional correlation spectroscopy: applications in vibrational and optical spectroscopy. John Wiley & Sons. (Haider, Chen et al. 2005).
  17. Haider, P., et al. (2005). "Application of the generalized 2D correlation analysis to dynamic near-edge X-ray absorption spectroscopy data." Journal of the American Chemical Society 127(6): 1906-1912.
  18. Noda, I. (1989). "Two-dimensional infrared spectroscopy." Journal of the American Chemical Society 111(21): 8116-8118.

entry.title: EvAX: RMC Refinement for Extracting 3D Structures from EXAFS Spectra
entry.content:
EvAX code is designed for the RMC-like analysis of well-defined structures, such as nanocrystalline materials.
The EvAX code is a simulation-based tool designed for the analysis of Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (EXAFS) data, specifically tailored for crystalline and nanocrystalline materials. This tool facilitates detailed studies of the atomic-scale structure within these materials, leveraging advanced simulation techniques to enhance the understanding of their properties.

Program dependencies

Authors

Janis TIMOSHENKO
EXAFS Spectroscopy Laboratory(EXAFS Lab)
Institute of Solid State Physics, University of Latvia
EXAFS Spectroscopy Laboratory
Recommendation: Cite the relevant publication.

J. Timoshenko, A. Kuzmin, J. Purans, J. Phys.: Condens. Matter 26 (2014) 055401 (15pp).

Installation

Download

FEFF8-lite EvAX Code Intel Fortran Compiler MinGW-w64

Compile

Edit the feff85L.f
Find ALL 130 definitions of parameters natx and nattx, and set the values of these parameters to, for example, 10000(To increse the default number of atoms for FEFF calculations)

Compile the FEFF8-L

  1. Install Interl Fortran Compiler
  2. open terminal

Config EvAX

Specify the path and name of your FEFF program in the input file for EvAX calculations.

In the latest version of EvAX, the author has included a compiled executable file named 'feff85L_jt.exe.' To use the program, simply download it and run the executable.

  • EvAX program
  • FEFF program

Overview

EvAX is a software program designed for the analysis of Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure data, utilizing Reverse Monte Carlo and Evolutionary Algorithm methods. It is particularly effective for research on materials with well-defined structures, such as nanocrystalline materials.
Key features:

  • Analysis of multiple scattering effects (Multiple-scattering effects contain useful structural information.)
  • Evolutionary algorithm-based structure optimization (RMC and EV)
  • Usage of wavelet transform for EXAFS signal comparison (Morlet wavelet or Gabor transform)
  • Analysis of EXAFS data from several absorption edges simultaneously (EvAX code allows one to construct an unambiguous single structure model, consistent with EXAFS data, acquired at several absorption edges.)

The Significance of EvAX

Pair Distribution Distance Disorder

EvAX restricts atomic displacements to only small shifts from their initial positions. This constraint allows for the modeling of complex bond-length distributions and facilitates the analysis of changes in interatomic distances and structural disorder. However, it does not permit the refinement of Coordination Numbers. Coordination Numbers are determined by the initial structural model provided by the user and remain unchanged during the EvAX simulations. Consequently, EvAX is particularly effective in scenarios where coordination numbers are predetermined, such as in the analysis of disorder in crystalline materials or well-defined nanocrystalline materials.

  • The approximate structure of the material are known. (From XRD ...)
    • EXAFS to study the disorder effects and atomic thermal motion
  • There are several plausible structure models for (From DFT,Molecular Dynamics ...)
    • to find which of them fits better with the experimental EXAFS data

Workflow

Preparation

  1. EvAX program
  2. FEFF program
  3. Parameter file (path to FEFF must be specified)
  4. Structure file (VESTA)
  5. Experimental file (With background substracted,e.g.Athena,EDA...)

All Calculation parameters (parameters.dat)

All commands

How EvAX works

In RMC simulation, the process begins with an arbitrary initial configuration of atoms within a cell of a specified size and shape, which may or may not incorporate periodic boundary conditions. The total EXAFS spectrum, denoted as , is calculated for this configuration. Subsequently, the atomic configuration is altered by randomly modifying the coordinates of one or several atoms, leading to a new configuration for which the total EXAFS spectrum, , is computed. The newly calculated EXAFS spectra, and , are then compared to the experimental spectrum . Based on this comparison, the new atomic configuration is either accepted or discarded. This procedure is repeated multiple times until the positions of the atoms in the cell minimize the difference between the theoretical and experimental EXAFS spectra.

Parameter file

Edit parameters.dat using any text editor.

STRUCTURE_MODEL_DEFINITION

Scale_coordinates_by

 Re-scale the atomic coordinates isotropically without modifying the structure file.
e.g.

File_with_structure

 Specify the name of text file which decribes the geometry of unit cell. Just .cif .xyz .p1(Recommended)
e.g.

Supercell

Set the size of simulation box (in unit cells).
e.g. 3x3x3 means a supercell consists of 3x3x3 unit cell.
If the first number in the Supercell parameter is larger than 0, but the next two is negative, EvAX will interpret the first number as the desired total number of atoms in the supercell. e.g. 100x-1x-1 will construct a supercell with approximatelly 100 atoms in total.

pbc

 Set periodic boundary conditions
e.g. use a XYZ file without information about periodicity of the material For crystalline materials

labels_to_element_name

 Set it to 1, EvAX will neglect the numerial symbols and treat all species with the same chemical symbol but different digits in the label as equivalent.
By default, EvAX considers atoms with the same chemical symbol but different digit as non-equivalent species.

Initial_displacement

 To save some calculation time, it is possible to apply some small random initial displacements for all atoms in the supercell. EvAX will displace all atoms in the structure model by vector , where , and are , sampled from uniform distribution, and is Initial_displacement parameter value.
Attention: It is always better to have a value of Initial_displacement that is too small rather than too large. By default, the value is which works well. To use automated procedure, set Initial_displacement to any negative value.
Attention: if value, obtained in such automatic procedure, exceeds significantly , it indicates that the initial structure model is poorly describing the Exp. data. (The model is completely wrong.)

Doping

 To simulate of random atom replacements(e.g. Solid solutions or Crystalline structures)

By default, the values for these parameters are none for Doping and -1 for Doping_level, both indicating that no replacements of atoms will take place.

Doping_level

 To simulate of random atom replacements(e.g. Solid solutions or Crystalline structures)

By default, the values for these parameters are none for Doping and -1 for Doping_level, both indicating that no replacements of atoms will take place.

Number_of_structures

Weight

STRUCTURE_MODEL_OPTIMIZATION

Move_type

 Specify the approach used during the simulations.

The atoms are displaced by vector , where , and are , is the maximal allowed step size.

Maximal_step_length

Specify the value for .
Recommended: . Smaller step sizes typically result in lower final residual, however, too small value wil result in a very slow initial evolution of the structure model. For calculations, where only one randomly selected atom is displaced, larger Maximal_step_length values can be used. By default, the value is .

Potential_type

 Create constraints.
Constrain the displacements of atoms from their initial positions that are known from diffraction experiments to be smaller than some given value Maximal _ displacement
Constrain the minimal allowed interatomic distances.
Use the combination of both constraints, and specify different constraints for atoms of different types.

More to see File_with_potential.

File_with_potential

 Specify the constraints file.
The format of file with constraints.

Maximal_displacement

 Create constraints.
Constrain the displacements of atoms from their initial positions that are known from diffraction experiments to be smaller than some given value Maximal _ displacement
Constrain the minimal allowed interatomic distances.
Use the combination of both constraints, and specify different constraints for atoms of different types.

More to see File_with_potential.

MT_seed

 Specify the sequence of pseudo-random numbers.

adjust_acceptance

 Specify whether to run the simulation such that only moves that improve the agreement between experiment and theory are accepted.
e.g.
is define as the difference between experiment and theory spectrum.
Local minimum If only moves where are accepted, the difference will always decrease, eventually it will reach the local minimum after some iterations.
Global minimum To find the global minimum, it is necessary to accept soome of the moves where . Metropolis algorithm. 
graph LR
A[Move] --> B{Is Condition1?}
B -- Yes --> C[Move is accepted]
B -- No --> D{Is Condition2?}
D -- Yes --> C
D -- No --> E[Move is discarded]

Condition1:
Condition2: ,where is a pseudo-random number in the range between 0 and 1, and is a scaling parameter, representing the standard deviation. (the characteristic width of the Boltzmann distribution).
"Large" and "Small" depend on system parameters. System parameters: number of atoms in the model, step size for atomic displacements, derivatives of particular EXAFS spectra with respect to atomic coordinates.
Rewrite the condition2,
is the Acceptance_rate, is the average change of the residual per iteration which depend on system patameter. See more to Acceptance_rate and Adjust_acceptance

Acceptance_rate

 Set the value of Acceptance_rate.
EvAX allows one to carry out RMC calculations with fixed value of The strongly remmended solution.

Froze_in

 Specify the length of the cooling schedule, .
After numbers of iteration reach the value of Froze_in, only the atomic displacements that are improving agreement between experiment and theory are accepted.
Boltzmann annealing schedule.
e.g.

Number_of_states

 Specify the number of individuals in the population.
This parameter is related to the Evolution algorithm in EvAX. Set the Number_of_states to a value larger than 1, optimization will be carried out via EA scheme. Recommended:

Stop_after

 Force EvAX to stop calculation after Stop_after iterations.

time2 [OUTPUT parameter]

 Specify the frequency of accuracy check
accuracy check for
e.g. the EXAFS calculation accuracy check will be repeated after each 100 iterations

Recommendation: Do not to be unnecessarily small value.

adjust_weights

Weight_increment

Energy_weight

EXPERIMENTAL_DATA

Number_of_spectra

Simultaneously to analyze several EXAFS spectra
If there are multiple spectra and different values of a particular parameter are required for analyzing each spectrum, all these values must be specified on the line corresponding to this parameter.
e.g.

parameters value
Number_of_spectra 2
File_with_experimental_EXAFS_signal Ni.dat Pt.dat
Edge Ni Pt
Edge_type K L3

File_with_experimental_EXAFS_signal

Specify the file name of experimental data
or with command

Columns_in_input

Specifying the Total Columns in a File

Column_for_k

Specifying the k Columns in a File

Column_for_chi

Specifying the Columns in a File

k_power_in_IO

Specify the k weight of
Note: The k-weight used for comparing the experimental (Exp.) versus theoretical (Theory) data is not set here.

S02

Specify

  • From conventional EXAFS analysis
  • Reference materials
  • Perform ExAX with different , choose the best one
  • Automatic (Not recommended!)

dE0

Specify dE0

  • From conventional EXAFS analysis
  • Reference materials
  • perform ExAX with different dE0, choose the best one
  • in the EvAX input file should be with the opposite sign
  • Automatic (Not recommended!)

THEORETICAL_DATA

more about SCF
Tools-FEFF

FEFF_path

Set path to FEFF

Edge

Specify the absorption Element.
Note: the label of the absorbing atom must be the same as specified in the structure file.
Normally one needs to use the same label for all absorbing atoms in the structure file (different labels can be used for non-absorbing atoms, though).

Edge_type

Specify the absorption Edge_type.

Polarization

 To carry out EXAFS calculations for a particular X-ray polarization

will carry out EXAFS calculations with X-ray polarization vector in (110) direction

r_scf

Specify the size of the atomic cluster
Default = 3rd coordination shell

n_scf

Specify the Maximum number of iterations for the potential calculations
Default = 30

n_mix

Specify the number of iterations
Default = 1

ca

Set the convergence accelerator factor which affects the convergence of self-consistent calculations.
Default = 0.1

Pathfinder_robustness

If the distance between corresponding points is less than the value specified by Pathfinder_robustness, then these paths will be grouped together into the same category.
Recommmendation:

R_max_for_FEFF

Set the maximal length for paths included int the calculations. (Not the R_max!)
represents the maximum value of for FEFF calculations. FEFF will include paths where the total length, , is less than .
R_max_for_FEFF parameter should normally be larger than parameter value.

N_legs

 Set the maximum value of the allowed path order.
e.g. only single- and double- scattering paths

FEFF_criteria

a group of paths with total contribution smaller than will be neglected.
Recommendation:

Clustering_precision

Set the convergence limit
If the difference between approximate and precise calculations exceeds , the parameter will be incremented by 1. This process continues until the calculations achieve the required level of accuracy.
Recommendation: Clustering_precision is 0.05. If multiple-scattering effects are contributing strongly, it is better to be smaller e.g. 0.001.

Maximal_number_of_clusters

Set the maximal total number of paths with calculated phases and amplitudes
e.g. if the total number of paths with calculated phases and amplitudes has reached Maximal_number_of_clusters$, further increase of will be interupted.

Update_basis_every_...

 Specify the phases and amplitudes needs to be recalculated
e.g. every second

Recommandation: Do not to be larger than 3.

Expansion_accuracy

 Specify the number of n (number of used central moments)
Using Taylor expansion to accelerate the calculation.
e.g.

Recommendation: 14 is reasonable if deviations from average path length do not exceed ca
Indication that needs to be increased is an unphysical increase in the amplitude of calculated EXAFS at high values.

THEORY_AND_EXPERIMENT_COMPARISON

Space

Specify the Space to compare data

  • k k-space
  • R Fourier Transform
  • q inverse Fourier Transform
  • w Wavelet Transform or Gabor Transform

k_power

Specify the k-weight for comparing Exp. and Theo.

k_min

Set
comprare the theo. and exp. with k range

k_max

Set
comprare the theo. and exp. with k range

dk

Set dk
k step. The data will be re-discretized on a mesh in k-space with step

FT_window_type

Specify the type of the windows function

  • Hanning Window
  • Gaussian Window (Default)

R_min

Specify the limitation of the R-range used for the comparison for exp. and theo. EXAFS data

R_max

Specify the limitation of the R-range used for the comparison for exp. and theo. EXAFS data

R0_for_WT

Specify the characteristic frequency of Morlet wavelet

  • Default

WT_type

Gabor Transform
R0_for_WT will be invalid.

R_max_for_1st_shell

Set the value of
EvAX performs conventional fit of the 1st coordination shell to estimate S0 dE0

adjust_spectra_weights

Allow EvAX to adjust weights automatically

Spectrum_weight

Set the value of weight
is the weithy of the i-th spectrum

OUTPUT

File_for_equilibrium_xyz

Specify the file name containing the complete list of Cartesian atomic coordinates.
The initial atomic configuration will be save to "File_for_equilibrium_xyz".

File_for_final_xyz

 Specify the file name of the current atomic coordinates.
The current atomic coordinate will be updated every time2 iterations.

File_for_i-pol._exp._signal

Specify the file name of the reinterpolated and corrected experimental spectrum.

File_for_FT_of_exp._signal

Specify the file name of the Fourier transform of the experimental spectrum.

Column 1 Column 2 Column 3 Column 4
R(frequencies) Real part Imaginary part Modulus(Magnitude)

File_for_BFT_of_exp._signal

Specify the file name of the inverse Fourier transform of the experimental spectrum.

Column 1 Column 2
k(wavenumber) the values of the Fourier-filtered EXAFS

File_for_WT_of_exp._signal

Specify the file name of the Morlet wavelet transform of the experimental spectrum.

Column 1 Column 2 Column 3 Column 4 Column 5
k(wavenumber) R(Frequencies) Real part Imaginary part Absolute value

File_for_FT

Specify the file name of the Fourier transform of the calculated spectrum.

Column 1 Column 2 Column 3 Column 4
R(frequencies) Real part Imaginary part Modulus(Magnitude)

File_for_BFT

Specify the file name of the inverse Fourier transform of the calculated spectrum.

Column 1 Column 2
k(wavenumber) the values of the Fourier-filtered EXAFS

File_for_WT

Specify the file name of the Morlet wavelet transform of the calculated spectrum.

Column 1 Column 2 Column 3 Column 4 Column 5
k(wavenumber) R(Frequencies) Real part Imaginary part Absolute value

File_for_calculated_EXAFS_signal

Specify the file name of the calculated spectrum.

File_for_partial_EXAFS

Specify the file name of partial_EXAFS
The order of paths is the same as in "path_fin.dat" file in "feff_0" directory.
The file is updated every time2 iterations.

Column 1 Column 2 ...
(wavenumber) p-th path ...

File_for_residuals

Specify the file name of the file that contains the information on the current difference between experimental and theoretical EXAFS data. Use the file to monitor the convergence of the EvAX calculations.

File_for_restart

Specify the file name for restart.

time2

 Specify the frequency of accuracy check
accuracy check for
e.g. the EXAFS calculation accuracy check will be repeated after each 100 iterations

Recommendation: Do not to be unnecessarily small value.

time1

Specify the frequency for updating the calculated data
While EXAFS spectra are recalculated at each iteration, they are saved to disk only after each time1 iterations. If evolutionary algorithm approach is used and several atomic configurations are modeled simultaneously, only the spectra that correspond to the configuration that gives the best agreement with experimental data are saved.

Column_for_k [EXPERIMENTAL_DATA parameter]

Specifying the k Columns in a File

Column_for_chi [EXPERIMENTAL_DATA parameter]

Specifying the Columns in a File

k_power_in_IO [EXPERIMENTAL_DATA parameter]

Specify the k weight of
Note: The k-weight used for comparing the experimental (Exp.) versus theoretical (Theory) data is not set here.

File_for_partial_RDFs

Specify the file name of RDFs.

RDF_bin_width

 Set the bin width of the histogram.
e.g.

File_for_partial_FT

Specify the file name of Fourier transform of partial_EXAFS

File_for_partial_WT

Specify the file name of Morlet wavelet transform of partial_EXAFS

PARALELIZATION

Number_of_threads

Specify the number of tasks.

Commands (flags)

  • A brief description of all commands or flags

  • Generate a file "example.dat"

  • On-line modify paraters.dat Note that the existing "parameters.dat" file will not be modified: the modified parameters fill be saved as a new file with the name, e.g., "parameters.dat_new".

  • Automatical calculate E0 S02

  • Set path to the Exp. Data file

  • Specify to avoid the recalculation of cluster potential. (relevant FEFF output files have been saved in "feff_0")

  • To generate FEFF input without launching the RMC calculations. Patamaters.dat need to specify the structure file and absorption edge, SCF parameters(Optional)

  • After modifing the "paths_fin.dat", to restarted the calculation

  • Run calculations without the accuracy check () (It is not recommended to use this option for other than testing purposes)

  • Calculate EXAFS spectra without RMC

  • Find the central absorbing atom automatically

  • Prevent ExAX from creating and saving and instead read from the exiting file ("windows_K_0")

    • to apply some different (non-rectangular) weights

  • Calculate Fourier, inverse Fourier and wavelet Transform for a given spectrum without RMC

  • Modify the seed parameter

    • EvAX will creat a copy of this file with the name "parameters.dat_reseed", where all calculation parameters are the same as in the original file, but the random generator seed is changed.

  • Extract the atomic coordinates and spectra, corresponding only to one atomic configuration that gives the best agreement between experiment and theory

EXAFS Calculations

Structure Model and Optimization

Principles

References

Author's Report

GLOBAL XAS JOURNAL CLUB TALK ABOUT RMC AND RELATED METHODS FOR XAS
Youtube Video:
EXAFS analysis using Reverse Monte Carlo and machine learning: XAS Journal Club

entry.title: FDMNES: A Computational Tool for Calculating X-ray Absorption and Emission Spectrum
FEFF: Advanced Tools for Calculating XAS and EELS Using Green's Functions Theory Spectrum Analysis
Identifying Quality EXAFS Data Fitting: Statistical Methods
Modeling Pair Distribution Functions Using DISCUC
entry.content: DISCUS is a comprehensive program designed to generate disordered atomic structures and compute corresponding experimental data, such as single crystal diffuse scattering or the atomic pair distribution function (PDF). Key features include symmetry operations, Monte Carlo simulation capabilities, and the ability to generate domain structures, among others. More recent developments in DISCUS have expanded its functionality to include the simulation of nanoparticles.

entry.title: Modeling Pair Distribution Functions Using PDFgui
entry.content: PDFgui offers a user-friendly graphical interface for the PDFfit2 refinement program, facilitating full-profile fitting of the atomic pair distribution function (PDF) derived from x-ray or neutron diffraction data. It includes built-in graphical and structure visualization capabilities, enhancing its utility and ease of use for researchers.

entry.title: Modeling Pair Distribution Functions Using RMCProfile
entry.content: The Reverse Monte Carlo (RMC) method offers a unique perspective on the atomic structure of matter, derived directly from experimental data. Primarily used to analyze neutron and x-ray total scattering data, RMC is particularly effective for studying disordered materials—materials for which other probes provide only limited information.

entry.title: Principles of Resonant inelastic X-ray Scattering
entry.content: X-ray Resonant Inelastic Scattering (RIXS) is an emerging excitation spectroscopy technique developed over the past decade. Leveraging the coupling of photons with the majority of degrees of freedom that determine material properties—including lattice, charge, spin, and orbitals—RIXS spectra can observe various excitations such as phonons, magnons, orbitons, and electronic level transitions, thereby providing rich physical information. Additionally, RIXS inherits the advantages of X-ray techniques, allowing its application in the measurement of low-dimensional materials and small samples. These benefits have positioned RIXS technology as a valuable tool in fields such as condensed matter physics, materials science, chemistry, and biology.

entry.title: Understanding of Powder Diffraction Patterns
entry.content: The best way to understand how structure information is encoded in a powder diffraction pattern is to view it as a series of discrete diffraction peaks(Bragg reflections) superimposed over a consecutive background. Despite the background can provide infomation about the crystallinity of the specimen and a few other material properties, the primary focus in analyzing material structure remains on the Bragg reflection peaks.

entry.title: Use Dioptas for Efficient 2D Powder Diffraction Data Reduction
entry.content:
Dioptas is an awesome GUI program based on Python, designed for the fast data reduction of Powder X-ray Diffraction images. It provides the capability of calibrating, integrating, creating masks, showing multiple pattern overlays and display phases line positions.

Program dependencies

Authors

Maintainer

Clemens Prescher (clemens.prescher@gmail.com)

Installation

Executables

Binary programs for Windows, macOS, and Linux can be downloaded from the following link:

pip

Install the all the dependencies for Dioptas by pip package manager:

poetry
Use the poetry package manager to create a working environment by typing:

Procedure

Overview

Dioptas has three different modules which can all be accessed by the lab indicators on the left side of the user interface: Calibration, Mask, Integration.

  • Calibration Module This module is used to calibrate the detector geometry.
  • Mask Module This module allows users to select regions that need to be excluded from the image integration.
  • Integration Module This module displays the image and integrated pattern. It can overlay different patterns and show the line positions of phases.

Getting Started

Basic Mouse Operations

  • Left Drag
  • Right Drag
  • Right Click
  • Right Double Click
  • Mouse Wheel
  • Left Drag Zooms into the selected area.
  • Right Drag Move the image.
  • Right Click Zoom out.
  • Right Double Click Completely Zoom out.
  • Mouse Wheel Zoom in and zoom out based on the current cursor position.

Image Color Scale and Contrast

The image color scale and contrast can be adjusted by sliding the color bar and right-clicking to change the color group.

Workflow

Step 1 Calibrate

Load the image data of the calibrant to perform the calibration and refinement procedures. Usually, the calibrant is a compound with a known and stable crystal structure, such as LaB6, CeO2, Cr2O3, etc. 

flowchart LR
    A(Load Image Data) -->B(Calibration)
    B --> C(Mask)
    C --> D(Integration)
    D --> E(Save Calibration or Export Data)

Step 2 Load 2D Image and Covert to 1D

Load the image data of samples to extract structural information. 

flowchart LR
    A(Load Image Data) -->B(Mask)
    B --> C(Integration)
    C --> D(Export Data)
    C --> A

Batch Mode Multiple data processing is discussed in Section 4.6 Integration Procedure.

Let's start by loading the image data.
Click the button the on the upper right side of the interface to begin the process.
  • Calibration
  • Mask
  • Integration

Calibration Procedure

The calibration procedure aims to correct the detector geometry and find the beam center.

Preparation

First, click the button located on the left side of the window to enter calibration mode. The wavelength and pixel width/height have to be defined based on the experimental setup and detector used.

Start values
Required Parameter Setting:

  • Calibrant (standard complex)
  • wavelength
  • pixel size (width, height)
  • Approximate Distance (the program will automatically refine the value)

Peak Picking

Peak Selection
After selecting the 'Calibration Parameter', Dioptas requires an initial guess for the ring positions to determine the correct geometry. Select several points on each diffraction ring to proceed. OK, now, left-click at the location where we believe the first diffraction ring appears. Calibration dose not need to start from the first diffraction ring.

Calibration does not need to start from the first diffraction ring, which enables calibration of detector geometries with the beam center being far outside of the area of the detector. But we ought to make sure that current peak number belongs to the corresponding clicked ring.

If the default automatic peak search is enabled, simply left-click the first diffraction ring as shown in this figure. Zooming in on the image will help accurately target the first ring.
If the automatic peak searching fails, we can try the following alternatives:

  • Perform the automatic search on the second, third, or subsequent rings.
  • Choose the single peak search option.
  • automatic peak search
  • single peak search

Left click the localtion of the fist diffraction rings. The peak search routine will automatically detect the remaining diffraction rings when we click the button, located at the bottom left.

Left-click on the location of a diffraction ring; the program will mark the maximum peak around the clicked area. The Search size determines the search area. We should select as many diffraction rings as possible. - one peak for one diffraction ring (select the automatic increase)

Calibrate and Refine

Calibrate

Calibrate
After the ring have been selected we can start the calibration procedure. button, located at the bottom left. When the procedure is finished, Dioptas will switch to the Cake Tab. We can click on the pattern table to check if all peaks in the pattern coincide with the phase line positions. Check whether the calibration is successful. - the cake lines are straight - all peak in the pattern are coincided with phase line position

Refinement Options

After calibration and refinement, Dioptas will automatically create a 360 degree cake image and an integrated pattern. Some options can be defined. For high-quality diffraction data, it is recommended to set the intensity minimum factor to about 1-1.5.
For other parameters, refer to the manual.

File Handing

Save Calibration
Save the calibration parameter as a .poni file for future use.
Load Calibration
Load a previously saved clibration.

Mask Creation

Create a mask to define areas that should be excluded from integration or calibration.

A mask excludes specific areas from the integration process, which enables the removal of unwanted features such as, for example, diamond reflections in diamond anvil cell experiments, saturated peaks or detector blemishes. Available geometries for creating masks are circles, rectangles and polygons.

  • mask
  • unmask

Mask

Choose a shape and left-click to set a start point, then drag the mouse to adjust the size of the shape, and finally left-click again to set the endpoint.

Unmask

Choose a shape and left-click to set a start point, then drag the mouse to adjust the size of the shape, and finally left-click again to set the endpoint.

File Handing

Save Mask
Save the mask as a .mask file for future use.
Load Mask
Load a previously saved mask and clear the current mask before
Add Mask
add Load a previously saved mask and add it into current mask.

Integration Procedure

The core component of Dioptas where we can automatically integrate multiple images to pattern, browse between images and integrated pattern, compare multiple pattern to each other, perform background subtraction and compare pattern peak positions and intensities to the ones of known phases.

Bathch Processing

Image

  • Check the autoprocess
  • Click the to set an input folder

Pattern

  • Check the autocreate
  • Click the to set an output folder

There are two mode for browing,

  • By Name test_001.tif test.002.tif ... | test_001.chi test_002.chi ...
  • By Time files will be searched based on creation time.

The output file type can be changed by checking the box in the lower right of the Pattern Tab.

Exporting Data

Click Save to save the pattern as the desired file type. If we click the 'Save' button on the left, we will save the Dioptas project.

References

[1] Prescher, Clemens, and Vitali B. Prakapenka. “DIOPTAS: A Program for Reduction of Two-Dimensional X-Ray Diffraction Data and Data Exploration.” High Pressure Research 35, no. 3 (2015): 223–30. doi:10.1080/08957959.2015.1059835.
[2] Dioptas 0.4.0 documentation
[3] github.com/Dioptas/Dioptas.git

Manual Github

entry.title: Wavelet analysis of EXAFS: Principle
Wavelet analysis of EXAFS: Tools
XAFS Theory
entry.content:
XAFS is an element-specific spectroscopy in which measurements are made by tuning the X-ray energy at and above a selected core-level binding energy of a specified element. Although XAFS is a well-established technique providing reliable and useful information about the chemical and physical environment of the probe atom, its requirement of an energytunable X-ray source means it is primarily done with synchrotron radiation sources and so is somewhat less common than other spectroscopic analytical methods. XAFS spectra are especially sensitive to the oxidation state and coordination chemistry of the selected element.

Theory

entry.title: diffpy.pdfgetx: Advanced Programs for Converting Powder Diffraction Data into Total Scattering Pair Distribution Functions
entry.content:
diffpy.pdfgetx3 is an advanced and powderful software for converting Powder Diffraction data to Total Scattering atomic Pair Distribution Funtions. In addtion, it can also help us to extrat the PDFs from small-angle scattering(SAS). The program include three command line programs PDFgetx3, PDFgetN3 and PDFgetS3 for processing X-ray, Nertron, and Small-angle diffraction data respectively.

Program dependencies

Authors

This code was written by members of the Billinge Group at Columbia University and Brookhaven National Laboratory including Pavol Juhás, Timur Davis, Chia-Hao (Timothy) Liu, Christopher Wright, Christopher Farrow, Connor J. Bracy, Hung Vuong, Songsheng Tao, Simon Billinge.
Prof. Simon Billinge (E-mail: sb2896@columbia.edu)
The Billinge Group
The BILLINGE GROUP: COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY
Department of Applied Physics and Applied Mathematics
The Billinge Group

Installation

Obtain the Software

The PDFgetX3, PDFgetN3 and PDFgetS3 software can be obtained for free from Columbia Technology Ventures, provided it will be used for open academic research (Recommendation: Cite the relevant paper.).

The Complicated process

Visit the official software website and follow the procedures at:

Install the Software

Download the appropriate version of Python for your operating system.
Download Python
In China, to speed up the downloading of packages via pip, it is recommended to use a domestic mirror site. Now, open the terminal and run the following command.

Other mirror,
Open Source Mirrors

Windows (not Recommended)

Open the terminal, CMD or Powershell and run,

Linux (Recommended)

Open the terminal and run,

Check Installation

pdfgerx3

Overview

PDF data analysis typically consists of three parts:

  • Obtaining one-dimensional diffraction data (e.g., using Fit2D, Dioptas)
  • Extracting the total scattering pair distribution function (PDF) from the diffraction data (e.g., using diffpy.pdfgetx)
  • Modeling analysis of the PDFs (e.g., using RMCProfile, DISCUS).

diffpy.pdfgetx can readily process hundreds of powder diffraction patterns within a few seconds. With an ad hoc data reduction and correction algorithm, pdfgetxns3 requires little user input, generates PDFs in a fraction of a second, and can be straightforwardly automated to batch process thousands of PDFs.

Workflow

Ensure that the two-dimensional data have been correctly azimuthally integrated and that multiple frames have been summed or averaged to obtain a one-dimensional profile of intensity versus Q or intensity versus .

flowchart LR
    A(Load .chi Data) -->B(Configuration)
    B --> C(Command)
    C --> D(Export Data)
    C --Refine parameter--> B

Get Started

Preparation

.chi file

The TwoTheta data or QA or Qnm data.
Such as,

Help

Open the Terminal and type the following command to access the help menu.

Then, switch to the filepath where we saved the data file.

Generate the Configuration

We should create the configuration file for the programs.
The default name for config files,

pdfgetx3 pdfgetn3 pdfgers3
pdfgerx3.cfg pdfgetn3.cfg pdfgets3.cfg
.pdfgetx3.cfg .pdfgetn3.cfg .pdfgets3.cfg

If a configuration file is not specified with the command, the program will search for pdfgetx3.cfg or .pdfgetx3.cfg to load.

Open the config file with a text editor. The lines that start with a hash mark # are comments and are exclueded. The Critial Options for PDFs calculation:

Options Description
dataformat twotheta or QA or Qnm
wavelength Required for TwoTheta Data. Radiation wavelength
composition Chemical composition of the specimen
qmaxinst Q boundary of the instrument
qmax Q cutoff range for Fourier Tansform

Run

The structure of command of pdfgerxns3 is

Options control the program, and 'inputN' specifies the total scattering data in a .chi file.

#for pdfgerx3
pdfgetx3 --verbode=info -t gr FileName.chi --plot=fq,gr
#for pdfgern3
pdfgetn3 --verbode=info -t gr FileName.chi --plot=fq,gr
#for pdfgets3
pdfgets3 --verbode=info -t gr FileName.chi --plot=fq,gr

#--verbose=info    -print the information
#-t gr   save the gr data (PDFs data)
#--plot=fq,gr    plot f(q) and g(r) also can plot i(q) and s(q)

Have a try.

Now, the program has finished, and we have obtained the PDFs with the file name extersion .gr. pdfgetxns3 enters an IPython session in interactive mode. For more about interactive mode, refer to Section Interactive Mode.

Input

Command

Output

Batch Processing

Interactive Mode

Physical Theory of PDFs

The PDF is a probability distribution function in real-space.

How to Obtain PDFs from Total Scattering

Coherent Scattering

The internsity measured in a total scattering experiment Im(Q)

  • Ic(Q) is the intensity of coherent scattering which contains all of the structural information about the sample Signal
  • a(Q) and b(Q) are additive and multipicative corrections to Im(Q) which do not contain structural information. (Such as Compton Scattering, Scattering from the sample container) Noise

Structure Function

To obtain the coherent scattering Ic(Q) we divide Im(Q) by the number of scatterers, N, and the average scattering powder per atom. So, we have accquired the structure function, S(Q).
For the X-ray Powder Diffraction or Small-angle Scattering,
Here, f(Q) is the atomic scattering factor and the angle brackets indicate an average over all the atom types in the sample.
For the Neutron Powder Diffraction or Small-angle Scattering,
where bi is the coherent neutron scattering length of atom i, and the angle brackets indicate an average over all atoms in the sample.

Tips:
Despite the tricky definition, it is worth remembering that S(Q) is nothing other than the powder diffraction pattern that has been corrected for experimental artifacts and suitably normalized.
Corrections include, but are not limited to, background subtraction, polarization, self-absorption, multiple scattering, and Compton scattering.

FT(Reduced Structure Function)

Total scattering data can be analyzed by fitting models directly in reciprocalspace (i.e., the S(Q) function is fit). However, an alternative and intuitive approach is to Fourier transform the data to real-space to obtain the atomic pair distribution functions (PDF), which is then fit in real-space. The reduced pair distribution function, , is related to S(Q) through a sine Fourier transform according to:

where the quantify F(Q) is the reduced structure function.

PDFs is the Fourier transform result of the reduced structure function F(Q).

Coherent scattering (also known as Rayleigh, unmodified, classical or elastic scattering) is one of three forms of photon interaction which occurs when the energy of the x-ray or gamma photon is small in relation to the ionization energy of the atom (for instance, during mammography). Such low-energy radiation triggers all the electrons in an atom to vibrate at a similar frequency to the incident photon. Upon interacting with the attenuating medium, the photon does not have enough energy to liberate the electron from its bound state (i.e. the photon energy is well below the binding energy of the electron) so no energy transfer occurs. There is no energy deposition and thus no dose resulting from coherent scattering. The only change is a change of direction (scatter) of the photon, hence 'unmodified' scatter. Coherent scattering is not a major interaction process encountered in radiography at the energies normally used.

Algorithm of pdfgetxns3

Data preprocessing

For data, it will be converted to the scattering vector magnitude Q and re-sampled onto an equidistant Q grid.

Note that resampling introduces error correlations between points, which can be minimized if the data are azimuthally integrated from two dimensions directly onto a constant-Q grid.

Q is the magnitude of the scattering vector, where: The vector is the physicist's equivalent of the crystallographer's . The physical meaning of is the momentum transfer on scattering and differs from the scattering vector by a factor of

Background Subtraction

The scattering data from an empty sample container will be subtracted.
This yeilds raw scattering intensities from the specimen only.

Normalization

Acquir the F(Q)
The S(Q) should oscillate around and the approach unity as Q increasing to infinity.

The coherent intensity (the features) in S(Q) dies out with increasing Q due to the Debye–Waller factor, which comes from thermal and quantum zero-point motion of the atoms as well as any static displacive disorder in the material. By a Q-value of 30–50 (depending on temperature and stiffness of the bonding) there are no more features in S(Q) and there is no need to measure to higher-Q.

This told us that the normalized intensity must be close to the normal scattering factor . pdfgetxns3 will use a least-squares to approach the normal scattering factor. Assumption of pdfgetxns3 algorithm:

  • the difference between Experimental Sm(Q) with the real S(Q) is
  • can be modeling by an n-th-degree polynomial

Allown for the following derivation:

Error

Finally, this leads an error signal , extending up to,

This means that the error signal arising from the ploynomial data correction is only present for lengths smaller than rploy (Smaller than the physically and chemically meaningful distance). For example, if rploy=0.8 Angstrom, the exist at lengths smaller than 0.8 Angstrom.

rpoly is chosen to be below the nearest neighbor bond distance in the material

Reference

[1] Juhás, P., Davis, T., Farrow, C. . and Billinge, S. . . (2013), PDFgetX3: a rapid and highly automatable program for processing powder diffraction data into total scattering pair distribution functions. J. Appl. Cryst., 46: 560-566. https://doi.org/10.1107/S0021889813005190
[2] Juhás, P., Louwen, J.N., van Eijck, L., Vogt, E. . and Billinge, S. . (2018), PDFgetN3: atomic pair distribution functions from neutron powder diffraction data using ad hoc corrections. J. Appl. Cryst., 51: 1492-1497. https://doi.org/10.1107/S1600576718010002
[3] Liu, C. H., Janke, E. M., Li, R., Juhás, P., Gang, O., Talapin, D. V., & Billinge, S. J. (2020). sasPDF: pair distribution function analysis of nanoparticle assemblies from small-angle scattering data. Journal of Applied Crystallography, 53(3), 699-709.
[4] https://www.diffpy.org/doc/pdfgetx/2.2.1/intro.html

Resources

PDFs: past and present

Zeitschrift für Kristallographie - Crystalline Materials

RA-PDF analysis

Journal of Applied Crystallography

Nature

Ab initio determination of solid-state nanostructure

A guide to PDFs

Zeitschrift für Kristallographie - Crystalline Materials

Science

The Problem with Determining Atomic Structure at the Nanoscale

Materialstoday

Nanostructure by high-energy X-ray diffraction

ChemComm

Beyond crystallography

Book

Underneath the Bragg peaks

Manual Online Doc.
